user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(uint32 ModeBits)
{
    char param[32];

    if (OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.EnableTermControl)
    {
        if (ModeBits == OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("sgr0", NULL);
        }
        else
        {
            if ((ModeBits & OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT) == 0)
            {
                /* no highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("rmso", NULL);
            }
            else
            {
                /* set highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("smso", NULL);
            }

            snprintf(param, sizeof(param), "%d", OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(ModeBits));
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(x) ((x)&0x07)
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL 0x0
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT 0x8
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
...
static void OS_BSP_ExecTput(const char *cap, const char *param)
{
    pid_t cpid;
    int   status;

    cpid = fork();
    if (cpid < 0)
    {
        return;
    }
    if (cpid == 0)
    {
        execlp("tput", "tput", cap, param, NULL);
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    waitpid(cpid, &status, 0);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in the provided code. Specifically:
- OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl takes ModeBits by value and it is only read (compared, bit-masked via macro) and never assigned to — no modification of the parameter occurs.
- The macro OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(x) expands to ((x)&0x07), which has no side effects and does not modify its argument.
- The local array param[] is a local object, not a function parameter, so using snprintf to populate it does not violate Rule 17.8.
- OS_BSP_ExecTput takes const char * parameters; inside that function the parameters are not reassigned (they are passed to execlp). Passing pointers to execlp does not constitute modifying the function parameter itself in C source — no assignment to the parameter variables occurs.
- No other functions in the shown code assign to their incoming parameters.
Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
